aboutGlossary.title: About This Glossary
aboutGlossary.paragraph1: This glossary contains comprehensive information about vision conditions and visual impairments. Each condition includes detailed descriptions of symptoms, causes, and effects on daily life.
aboutGlossary.paragraph2: Conditions marked with "Featured in:" are associated with famous individuals in our simulator. Click the eye icon next to any condition to experience it in our vision simulator.
aboutGlossary.paragraph3: This resource is designed to help users understand the various ways vision can be affected, whether through genetic conditions, injury, disease, or other factors.

aboutFaq.title: About These FAQs
aboutFaq.paragraph1: These frequently asked questions are based on common misconceptions and genuine curiosity about blindness and visual impairment. The answers reflect the diverse experiences of blind and visually impaired individuals.
aboutFaq.paragraph2: Remember that every person's experience with vision loss is unique. What works for one person may not work for another, and it's always best to ask individuals about their specific needs and preferences.
aboutFaq.paragraph3: For more detailed information about specific vision conditions, visit our Glossary tab above.

darkness.question: Do blind people see complete darkness/blackness?
darkness.answer: Not necessarily. About 85% of legally blind people have some remaining vision. Only 10-15% experience total darkness. Many see light/shadow, colors, or blurry shapes. Some who've never had sight don't experience "blackness" as a concept - similar to how you don't "see" blackness behind your head.

technology.question: How do blind people use smartphones and computers?
technology.answer: Screen readers (JAWS, NVDA, VoiceOver) convert text to speech or braille. Gestures and keyboard shortcuts replace mouse use. Many use normal smartphones with built-in accessibility features. Voice assistants like Siri are heavily utilized.

independence.question: Can blind people live independently?
independence.answer: Yes. With proper training and adaptive techniques, blind people cook, clean, work, raise families, and live fully independent lives. They use systematic organization, tactile markers, assistive technology, and mobility tools.

navigation.question: How do blind people navigate and get around?
navigation.answerIntro: Blind people use various methods for navigation and mobility:
answerItems: White canes detect obstacles and elevation changes
Guide dogs provide intelligent disobedience and navigation
GPS apps with audio directions (Soundscape, BlindSquare)

senses.question: Do blind people have heightened other senses?
senses.answer: No, their other senses aren't biologically superior. They develop better attention to and processing of audio/tactile information through practice and necessity. It's enhanced perception, not enhanced sensation.

interaction.question: How should I interact with a blind person?
interaction.answerIntro: Here are some important guidelines for respectful interaction:
answerItems: Speak normally and directly to them, not through companions
Ask before helping - don't grab or push
Use normal language ('see you later' is fine)
Never pet or distract guide dogs

legalVsTotal.question: What's the difference between legally blind and totally blind?
legalVsTotal.legallyBlindDesc: Vision 20/200 or worse with correction, OR visual field less than 20 degrees
legalVsTotal.mostBlind: Most "blind" people fall somewhere between these extremes.

employment.question: Can blind people work regular jobs?
employment.answer: Yes. Blind people work as lawyers, teachers, programmers, musicians, psychologists, business owners, and countless other professions. Workplace accommodations (screen readers, braille displays) enable most jobs.

identification.question: How do blind people identify money, colors, or objects?
identification.answerIntro: Blind people use various adaptive techniques for identification:
answerItems: Money: Apps like Seeing AI, different folding methods, electronic identifiers, and different sizes for different denominations in various countries
Colors: Color identifier apps, asking others, buying pre-matched clothing
Objects: Systematic organization, braille/tactile labels, voice recording labels, memory

causesTreatment.question: What causes blindness and can it be cured?
causesTreatment.treatmentInfo: Treatment depends on cause. Some conditions are preventable/treatable, others currently aren't. Research continues on treatments like gene therapy, stem cells, and bionic eyes.
causesTreatment.neurologicalNote: People can also lose their vision from neurological conditions like trauma or stroke.

about.title: About VisionSim
about.subtitle: Understanding our mission and approach
about.greeting: Hello to the Blind and Visually Impaired community — and to everyone curious to learn more!
about.story: In 2020 I lost my vision in an instant due to a stroke, and I struggled alone during the COVID shutdown, unable to find in-person rehabilitation, therapy, orientation classes, or anything. Looking online, I found next to nothing regarding stroke-related vision loss at the scale I experienced it. Accurately describing how I "see" the world was painfully difficult, and only added to the isolation.
about.purpose: I created this site so that people would be better equipped with tools to more accurately articulate and represent their blindness and/or vision conditions.
about.missionText: VisionSim helps people understand what it's like to live with various vision conditions through accurate, research-based simulations.
about.disclaimerText: These simulations are for educational purposes only and may not perfectly represent how individuals experience their conditions.
